job_title: Respiratory Therapist in Marin City, CA
pros: Work life balance, location, great patient population
cons: Bad management, politics, bullying by middle management

pros: The therapist is provided with one hour of time to treat a patient with complete freedom of treatment style.  Staff is supportive of each other.  There is scheduled documentation time and scheduled staff meetings and inservices.  The therapy manager is objective, calm and fair minded.  There is a large open gym and two private treatment rooms with closing doors--a third private room is available  two days a week.  Hand therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy and wound care are available within the building complex and you can cross refer as appropriate as well as confer with these disciplines.
cons:
The treatment gym is very ugly and has antiquated  equipment.  It does project an atmosphere of healing.  would benefit from an  influx of  beauty and feng shui.
If there is an schedule opening the therapist  may be required to work in the associated hospital which is a very scary place servicing the sickest of the sick and the morbidly obese in very tiny rooms.  
oh yes, and you have to clock in a time clock--even if you have your DPT--yes, doctor you must punch a clock.  of course the MD's don't have to.

pros: a few nice nurses, most ofthe staff seem tofeelbad about to conditions of the patients,
cons: no care, patients in agony , decub ulcers growing to cavernous sizes

review_title: Small and tight knit community of people trying to do their jobs as best they can to provide excellent patient care.
pros: There are many opportunities to get involved with multidisciplinary committees, different areas of practice, and start projects within your department. You cannot get the same level of involvement in larger organizations as an individual. You get to know everyone from different departments, which makes it easier to find answers and get things done.
cons: There is a definite lack of structured education for staff and a steep learning curve for new employees who are often coming into this hospital as their first job out of school. As a for-profit company, the labor budget is tightly controlled, and staff is often overwhelmed with assigned tasks and little help for the increasing acuity of the patient population. Most experienced staff tend to move on to other opportunities within only a few years due to lack of support/increasing demands on few high performing staff.

pros: Best part was working along particular staff that do not mind sharing information to assist with new staff. There is only a small handful.
cons:
here is a definite lack of structured education for staff and a steep learning curve for new employees who are often coming into this hospital as their first job out of school. As a for-profit company, the labor budget is tightly controlled, and staff is often overwhelmed with assigned tasks and little help for the increasing acuity of the patient population. Most experienced staff tend to move on to other opportunities within only a few years due to lack of support/increasing demands on few high performing staff.
Senior mgmt only care about the funds, with no support to their clinical staff to include overworking their physicians.

review_title: A great place to learn and practice many nursing skills
pros: Numerous learning opportunities, good communication/teamwork with other disciplines at the hospital. Friendly staff.
cons: Management seems disconnected from the workforce that is the backbone of this facility. Many senior nurses have become complacent, insisting they don't want to learn anything new because they feel nothing ever changes. Some of the Clinical House Supervisors are so disconnected from working the floor that they cannot help with any clinical skills beyond verbal communication with doctors and patient family members.

pros: If you like to work hard and you're up for a challenge, then you will discover Kentfield Hospital to be a remarkable employer. This is a fast paced environment with positive leadership. The people that will succeed are hard-working and positive.
cons: No cons. This company cares about their employees.

pros: Management cares, nurses work together and are supportive and friendly. Average patient stay is 32 days so nurses get to know them well. Flexible scheduling and fair critiques of performance. I would only recommend this position as a stepping stone to a better career.
cons: Acuity level is higher and job demand is greater. 5:1 staffing ratio can be overwhelming. A majority of the CNA's are not cooperative and some of them are insubordinate with nurses. Very fast paced environment.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Kentfield, CA
pros: We all work together no matter your job title and it is very much appreciated. Great staff who I feel seem very caring and that matters.
cons: The patient to nurse & patient to cna ratio sometimes to high especially because of the level of care needed for these patients..

pros: Many good people work here. Really enjoy my work. Love the nursing staff. Very nice facilities. A great place to learn.
cons: Underpaid. Too many chiefs and not enough Indians. Micromanaged at times. New nurses teaching new nurses as preceptors. Seasoned nurses lacking.

pros: Supportive , friendly staff in an acute care environment.
cons: RN's under market value. High turnover.  RN's not unionized. Not much support for nursing staff.

pros: Administration is very supportive. Staffs are pleasant and friendly.
